text: I now see that “bash for the cloud” is not a good way to resonate. The truth is we are *NOT* bash in the cloud, but like bash, we make accessing software single commands. Eg. `git push...` would also be `git push` in Storyscript but in the cloud. I like to think it’s a better bash but cloud focused.

text:
> how to build a webserver
I see your point. The thing we wanted to do is get your something *real* immediately. So a hello-world is kinda the first thing dev’s do when trying a language (generally speaking). Do you feel there is a more valuable example? One issue we have seen is that when we use “slack bots” or “twitter streamers” the reaction from most is thinking that is all we do :disappointed: which is sad and not representative of what we really can do.

> You need a better example to show off its strengths.
We have examples at <https://github.com/storyscript/examples> — I agree a better example would be nice.

> Maybe you receive a request and make a request elsewhere?
Like this: <https://storyscript.io/blog/story-telling/> (scroll to about mid page)

> Or make a request elsewhere and postprocess its results before sending them back?
That could be cool! I do think something usable and not to abstract is best. Otherwise, IMO the developer could get lost in the “why” rather than experiencing the product’s power.

attachments.title: Storytelling your next application
attachments.text: A tutorial on how to develop an application through story telling; building applications in a fraction of the time with zero-devops.

text:
> RE Top-level
Oh man! We have to so much :thumbsup: for that concept. Most in-fact think it’s perfect. I do believe it’s top-level as far as *programming* goes. IFTTT is unquestionably *low-code* while other products our there have *no-code* which are real industry teams accepted. I don’t think anyone would call IFTTT top-level, they would get the title of “low-code”, would you agree?

text:
I don't see too many flaws at first glance. The big one that stands out is the usage of try/catch, which is a horrendous way to handle errors. You are going to have a ton of errors in your system, where the things you are connecting to are going to fail to respond in a timely manner. Intrinsically, these services are finite state machines, yet you have no syntax for FSM. This is a huge omission, and will come to haunt you later.  try/catch is not going to deliver the necessary granularity to debug flaky interactions.

 I would suggest elif for chaining IF statements as the extra typing is unnecessary.  I would suggest using NOT instead of !, and <> for not equal, as i do in beads as the exclamation point is one of the precious punctuation marks you might want to use later in your evolution.

elements.text:
I don't see too many flaws at first glance. The big one that stands out is the usage of try/catch, which is a horrendous way to handle errors. You are going to have a ton of errors in your system, where the things you are connecting to are going to fail to respond in a timely manner. Intrinsically, these services are finite state machines, yet you have no syntax for FSM. This is a huge omission, and will come to haunt you later.  try/catch is not going to deliver the necessary granularity to debug flaky interactions.

 I would suggest elif for chaining IF statements as the extra typing is unnecessary.  I would suggest using NOT instead of !, and <> for not equal, as i do in beads as the exclamation point is one of the precious punctuation marks you might want to use later in your evolution.

text: As another minor note, it has proven dangerous from past experience to have a beginning block delimiter be identical the ending block delimiter. So ### should not be start and stop, because once you delete one of them, you have now flipped the meaning of what is commented versus not commented. So C uses /* ... */, Modula-2 uses (*... *), you might consider >>> .... <<< or some other symmetrical but not identical delimiter.

elements.text: As another minor note, it has proven dangerous from past experience to have a beginning block delimiter be identical the ending block delimiter. So ### should not be start and stop, because once you delete one of them, you have now flipped the meaning of what is commented versus not commented. So C uses /* ... */, Modula-2 uses (
), you might consider >>> .... <<< or some other symmetrical but not identical delimiter.

text:
> The big one that stands out is the usage of try/catch,
100% agree. We intentionally are holding back on a better implementation for a couple months to learn more about the type and frequency of errors.

Also, we do have a dashboard (not announced yet) that is powerful error management. So it’s not “just” a language but a language+tools+*dashboard*. I’m not sure there is any other language that has an integrated dashboard for error management. Think a native Sentry+Heroku Dashboard built exclusively for Storyscript.

> I would suggest elif for chaining IF statements as the extra typing is unnecessary.
:thumbsup: we have an open issue talking about this and it’s very likely to be added in about a week.

> I would suggest using NOT instead of !, and <> for not equal,
We are going with `not` instead of `!` — That was decided this week :thumbsup:

`<>` is interesting… I’ll bring it up to the team. IMO it’s a little too different than what people are familiar with.

text: And by the way when you click "debugging" in the docs you get a 404 page not found error. How you are going to debug these scripts is one of the key aspects of your system, since 80% of the time spent programming is consumed in the debug phase, and your language will be no different.

text:
> RE debugging
This deserves the upmost respect and thoughtfulness. We are most certainly not ignoring it. However, debugging is not-so-traditional for us. Since we have polyglot microservices under-the-hood we now have a beautiful separation of errors: ie. Internal vs Service. So we have innovated new ways to handle errors based on their source. More on this will be coming out soon.

elements.text: RE debugging

Since we have polyglot microservices under-the-hood we now have a beautiful separation of errors: ie. Internal vs Service. So we have innovated new ways to handle errors based on their source. More on this will be coming out soon.

text: nice to see a time fundamental type, however, it appears that it doesn't cover calendar dates. I think this will cause immediate problems, as many business processes are tied to calendars, so you either need to extend time to include a date+ time, or add a date data type. The current unix cron syntax is horrendous, and i am sure you can improve upon this easily.

elements.text: nice to see a time fundamental type, however, it appears that it doesn't cover calendar dates. The current unix cron syntax is horrendous, and i am sure you can improve upon this easily.

text:
But we have everything one would expect:
metrics, logs, tracebacks but with more.
A powerful and highly-integrated dashboard. Built-in AB testing. Built-in auto-failover. Deep integration with GitHub for error exposure (much like Sentry for example). Feature flags and much more.

text: for block comments if you want to stay with # as the starting punct, you could use #>>> ..... <<<# for example

elements.text: for block comments if you want to stay with # as the starting punct, you could use #>>> ..... <<<# for example

text: In the Beads language we offer 2 block comment syntaxes, and support nesting, because commenting out a big block of code that has comments inside is painful if nesting is not supported. C has this problem, and it is huge. We offer 2 different block comments because it is helpful when trying to find the end of a block if you only use a special one for big runs of code.

elements.text: In the Beads language we offer 2 block comment syntaxes, and support nesting, because commenting out a big block of code that has comments inside is painful if nesting is not supported. C has this problem, and it is huge. We offer 2 different block comments because it is helpful when trying to find the end of a block if you only use a special one for big runs of code.

text: I could go on for hours about all the subtleties of supporting comments, and how it interacts with computer generated code, but one should always make it easy and convenient to put in comments, because lazy people don't do it. Comments are for the humans reading the code, the code is for the computer.

elements.text: I could go on for hours about all the subtleties of supporting comments, and how it interacts with computer generated code, but one should always make it easy and convenient to put in comments, because lazy people don't do it. Comments are for the humans reading the code, the code is for the computer.

text: There is an abhorrent trend where relatively inexperienced programmers are now proudly stating they refuse to comment. If they had to work on some 300k line program left behind by sadists, they wouldn't be so proud of their lack of commenting. It a curse on future generations to do anything than your best effort to make it easier for the next person to understand your program.

elements.text: There is an abhorrent trend where relatively inexperienced programmers are now proudly stating they refuse to comment. If they had to work on some 300k line program left behind by sadists, they wouldn't be so proud of their lack of commenting. It a curse on future generations to do anything than your best effort to make it easier for the next person to understand your program.

text: I am not a fan of arrays based on 0. This is a hangover from C where an array was basically nothing more than an alias to a pointer, and a zero offset was the first element. There is not a human being who is taught to count starting with 0. If you tell a kid to count to five you go  1, 2, 3, 4, 5. So not sure why you are going to continue this unnatural practice of 0 based. Your language is interpreted. In Beads we start at 1 by default, however arrays are sparse and thus you can have negative subscripts, not to mention enumerated type subscripts. You probably don't need that kind of power, but since your language is targeting a very high level, it is incongruous to my thinking to inherit an assembly language level piece of thinking.

elements.text: I am not a fan of arrays based on 0. This is a hangover from C where an array was basically nothing more than an alias to a pointer, and a zero offset was the first element. There is not a human being who is taught to count starting with 0. If you tell a kid to count to five you go  1, 2, 3, 4, 5. So not sure why you are going to continue this unnatural practice of 0 based. Your language is interpreted. In Beads we start at 1 by default, however arrays are sparse and thus you can have negative subscripts, not to mention enumerated type subscripts. You probably don't need that kind of power, but since your language is targeting a very high level, it is incongruous to my thinking to inherit an assembly language level piece of thinking.

text: It is also inevitable that you will need to support breaking out of a nested loop, so you will need to have optional loop labels for that case where you want to continue the outer loop, or break out of nested loops.

elements.text: It is also inevitable that you will need to support breaking out of a nested loop, so you will need to have optional loop labels for that case where you want to continue the outer loop, or break out of nested loops.

text: i also think the end command should probably have an optional error return code, as sub-scripts may fail in different ways, and being able to detect the kind of error will be occasionally needed. A script is like calling a function; it may need to pass information back up the chain.

elements.text: i also think the end command should probably have an optional error return code, as sub-scripts may fail in different ways, and being able to detect the kind of error will be occasionally needed. A script is like calling a function; it may need to pass information back up the chain.

text: Lobster can only ignore a type error if it is in a statically dead code path, e.g. `if 1 == 2: 3 / "hello"` compiles just fine.

elements.text: Lobster can only ignore a type error if it is in a statically dead code path, e.g.
if 1 == 2: 3 / "hello"
compiles just fine.

text:
I see. I wasn't talking about dynamic type checks but static checks that, when they find a problem, inject code like an unconditional 'raise Exception' into the generated code. If that code path is not actually hit during runtime, it wont be an error. It could be the users choice whether they want to run in this half broken state. This gets you one happy face in the 4th row of Yair's comparison table :smile:

The use case is when you make a change to a function (e.g. remove an argument) but don't want to fix-up all the callers before you get to try the one caller that you're interested in at this point.

text: Full control of the language gives you a rare opportunity for some genuinely amazing debugging experiences here. I can’t speak for every other Bret Victor fan here, (because there are so many of us in this Slack) but it’s the debugging demos he created for _Inventing on Principle_ and _Learnable Programming_ that took me from “wow, these are cool ideas” to _clawing at the screen because I want this so badly_.

and
Learnable Programming
that took me from “wow, these are cool ideas” to

text: One of the key lessons from _Inventing on Principle_ absolutely applies to your domain: when the debugging tools are good and fast enough, they stop being just for diagnosis, and open up new ways to rapidly experiment and iterate on ideas. That’s a huge and emotive differentiator in this market.

text: I agree that 'top-level' sounds condescending, and I would avoid the hierarchy metaphor altogether if you can't find a way around that. Remember that the levels change every 10 years anyway so it's all silly! Ditto any mention of 'world's first' anywhere!
